There are some really creepy moments, but director Vincenzo Natali doesn’t push the perversity hard enough to take it into the deep twistedness that Cronenberg exploits so effectively.

version.name: Leap Year
version.plot: Trans-Atlantic romantic comedies often reach for easy stereotypes, but few have managed to be as patronising as Leap Year
version.review:
Trans-Atlantic romantic comedies often reach for easy stereotypes, but few have managed to be as patronising as Leap Year, in which superficial Bostonian Anna (Amy Adams) totters over to Ireland for a love-hate relationship with beardy, muttering Irishman, Declan (Matthew Goode). The plot centres on the idea of a woman proposing on February 29 – an Old Irish Tradition, we are told 500 times, as if we’d never heard of it. Anxious for a rock on her finger, Anna flies to Ireland to propose to her boyfriend Jeremy (Adam Scott), who’s working in Dublin. Re-routed because of bad weather, she must squeeze her designer luggage into the banger driven by Declan, and question her heart when he turns out not to be a complete Neanderthal.
While there’s some chemistry between the pair, it’s not enough to compensate for their paper-thin characters, never mind all the cross-eyed Guinness-swilling extras and the endless winding country roads that supposedly lead to Dublin. Adams does her level best, but her perkiness quickly wears as thin as her spiky heels on those pesky rural roads.

version.name: Despicable Me
version.plot: Quirky animation with the voice of Steve Carell
version.review:
What if supervillains lived among us? That’s the question posed by this fitfully amusing animated feature, which follows a hulking, Lugosi-accented baddie named Gru (Steve Carell) as he tries to steal the moon (yes, the moon). Gru is the kind of guy who’ll make a balloon animal to soothe a crying child – and then pop it. But his malicious genius is barely in demand, thanks to Vector (Jason Segel), who’s stolen the Great Pyramid of Giza and hidden it in his backyard.
Vector also has a shrink ray that Gru needs to pinch so he can get a scheme-funding loan from the Bank of Evil (‘formerly Lehman Brothers’ – the film’s best joke). What better way to make his nemesis lower his guard than with a doe-eyed trio of cookie-selling orphans?
The setup is pure Looney Tunes, and Despicable Me is at its best when trading in anything-for-a-laugh prankery. Gru’s yellow, gibberish-spouting minions are the most reliable chuckle-generators: one of them is the subject of a glow-stick gag that should make even the grumpiest audience member laugh out loud. And there are some terrific throwaway rib-ticklers, such as Vector’s hilariously useless ‘piranha gun’ and the Bank of Evil’s crush-the-little-man decor.
But sentiment soon overwhelms the subversiveness, as Gru learns that being a family guy is preferable to world domination. The more the character loses his antisocial edge, the more he becomes a Disneyfied dullard. Still, let’s see Aladdin get down to the Bee Gees.

version.name: The Haunting in Connecticut
version.plot: A family moves to a house that turns out to be a former mortuary and violent, paranormal events ensue
version.review: A family moves to a house that turns out to be a former mortuary and violent, paranormal events ensue. We didn’t see this week’s zillionth-rate horror release, but we doubt we missed much. Don’t be fooled by the film’s surprisingly robust US box office performance – movie website www.rottentomatoes.com has rated it 81 per cent ‘rotten’.

version.name: Killers
version.plot: Be afraid, be very afraid: Killers distributor Lionsgate has taken the unusual step of ensuring its Ashton Kutcher/Katherine Heigl
version.review:
Be afraid, be very afraid: Killers distributor Lionsgate has taken the unusual step of ensuring its Ashton Kutcher/Katherine Heigl-starring rom-com isn’t seen by critics before the release date, with a statement from the studio insisting the move was a unique marketing strategy that would ‘give the opportunity to moviegoing audiences and critics alike to see Killers simultaneously’. Which basically means: it stinks, and they know it.
It’s unsurprising, considering the film is yet another uninventive ‘Franken-rom-com’, this time stitching together box-office disasters such as Mr and Mrs Smith and My Mom’s New Boyfriend. A whirlwind romance ends in marriage but, unbeknown to the wife (Heigl), the husband (Kutcher) is an ass-kickin’ CIA agent. Then it turns out one of the couple’s friends is an assassin sent to kill them. If you’re not yet feeling uninspired, bear in mind that Kutcher is one of the most charmless leading romantic boy-men to ever sully our screens, while Heigl lumbers from one audience-repelling stink pile to the next (remember The Ugly Truth?). That and the studio’s lack of confidence considered, we’re willing to bet this would be Dhs30 badly spent.

version.name: Salt
version.plot: Jolie locks ’n’ loads into kick-ass mode for this thriller
version.review:
StarsAngelina Jolie, Liev Schreiber
The pitchJolie locks ’n’ loads into kick-ass mode for this thriller, wherein she’s a CIA agent accused of being a Russian spy who’s out to kill the president. Is she? Isn’t she?
The wordMs Jolie’s action abilities have always proved sufficient, it’s just the films surrounding them that are problematic (Tomb Raider; Mr and Mrs Smith; Wanted). No doubt she’ll put in another bruising performance – could this be the flick that’s worth it?

version.name: Inception
version.plot: Tale of a future in which crimes can be committed and solved in dreams
version.review:
Stars
Leonardo DiCaprio, Ellen Page, Marion Cotillard, Michael Caine
The pitchChristopher Nolan cashes in the goodwill he accrued on The Dark Knight with a self-penned tale of a dystopian future in which crimes can be committed – and solved – within the landscape of people’s dreams. DiCaprio plays a corporate ‘dream thief’ wrongly accused of murder.
The word The studio are keeping this one tightly under wraps, but the trailer is an intriguing mash-up of straightforward action and loopy visuals. The Minority Report-style hero-on-the-lam routine may seem like old hat, but we trust Nolan to infuse it with a sense of freshness – if he really pushes the dream invasion idea, this could be both a psychedelic visual feast and a gripping action thrill ride.

movie.name: Prince of Persia: The Sands of Time

version.name: Prince of Persia: The Sands of Time
version.plot: Jake Gyllenhall in a wig. Surely, no good will come of this?...
version.review:
Ever since we heard there was going to be a Prince of Persia movie, we were put in mind of Pirates of the Caribbean: a concept familiar to everyone, but with little or no actual story behind it (here, swap theme park ride for platform video game). Funnily enough, the connection is not solely superficial: like Pirates, this is a Disney affair produced by Hollywood big-hitter Jerry Bruckheimer (Beverly Hills Cop; Top Gun; Con Air; Pearl Harbour). And aye, there’s the rub: we suspect Prince will inherit all of Pirates’ problems, without its sole saviour to rescue it. Really – would we all have flocked to watch ghost pirates and bland romantic match Keira Knightley and Orlando Bloom were it not for Johnny Depp’s left-field lunacy as Captain Jack?
Like Pirates, Prince is saddled with a storyline that appears to have been cooked up in a blind panic, as though someone realised they’d forgotten to concoct a plot just as the cameras started to roll. It involves some guff about a mystical dagger that, when a ruby on the handle is clicked, sends the possessor of the dagger a minute back in time. (Expect the plastic, non-time-shifting model in Toys R Us any day now). There wasn’t a press screening before we went to print, but from the trailer it seems the kitsch extends beyond this to the sets, costumes and cheesy banter between prince in question Jake Gyllenhall and feisty princess Tamina, played by Brit up-and-comer Gemma Arterton.
As a kids’ movie, this is perfectly acceptable: the cartoonish elements will befit a young audience. But the PG13 rating suggests Prince of Persia is aiming for an older, more action-oriented crowd, and this could prove a costly mistake. Imagine Pirates carried only by Knightley and Bloom, with no deliciously demented Depp to sustain our interest. Doesn’t work, does it? No doubt Gyllenhaal and Arterton are perfectly competent, but where’s that missing sprinkle of magic?
Prince of Persia will likely do steady box office business, yet we’ll be surprised if it’s the highlight of summer 2010. Given Disney’s rather obvious banking on it becoming a cash-raking franchise, perhaps the best we can hope for is a rethink, followed by a re-energised part two.

version.name: Robin Hood
version.plot: Does the world really need another Robin Hood movie?
version.review:
Does the world really need another Robin Hood movie? Apparently Ridley Scott isn’t a fan of the myriad previous efforts, declaring Mel Brooks’ 1993 send-up Robin Hood: Men in Tights his favourite take so far. But for all the histrionic trailers that paint this fifth collaboration with Russell Crowe as an action-packed Gladiator-in-the-woods, we suspect that a tired concept might a tiring movie make. There weren’t any press screenings before we went to print, but word on the street suggests Robin Hood is a lot slower than those sword-swinging trailers would have you believe.
We also find ourselves unconvinced by the cast. A portly Crowe sporting a 21st century haircut and a penchant for long speeches doesn’t exactly inspire us to camp out at the ticket desk, and Cate Blanchett seems a brave choice for fair Maid Marian. Isn’t she a little – dare we say it – mature? Plus, Matthew Macfadyen (an underwhelming Darcy in Joe Wright’s Pride and Prejudice) scarcely appears in the trailers, yet he plays the Sheriff of Nottingham. Are the filmmakers that scared of Alan Rickman’s shadow?
It may be this week’s biggest release – hence its ‘Film of the week’ status – but we’re a little unconvinced by Ridley Scott’s Robin Hood. As summer blockbuster season shapes up to be a two-horse race – comic-book heroes (Kick-Ass; Iron Man 2) vs. epics (Clash of the Titans; Robin Hood; Prince of Persia next week) – we’ve a sneaking suspicion that capes are going to be cooler than sandals in 2010.

version.name: Wall Street: Money Never Sleeps
version.plot: Oliver Stone and Michael Douglas are back on the trading floor
version.review:
Oliver Stone is back on the trading floor and Michael Douglas is back in the sharp suits as the director attempts to resurrect his ’80s tale for modern times, combining melodrama with up-to-the-minute social and economic commentary. Jacob (LaBeouf) is a mindful and smart young trader at a Wall Street bank, where he enjoys the support and mentorship of a banking boss of the old school (Langella) and is on the verge of ploughing money into an eco-business he’s identified as a safe, responsible investment. But the good vibes can’t last.
Stone’s lightweight and soapy film feels like he threw a whole load of newspaper clippings at a tired plot about estranged fathers and a clash of values. The problem with this film is that if you put it in front of a bunch
of bankers, they’d laugh their heads off and feel a swell of pride at the thought that they inhabit a world as glamorous as that suggested. It’s hardly satire.

version.name: Piranha
version.plot: An earthquake releases shoals of prehistoric piranha into Lake Victoria
version.review:
When an underground earthquake releases shoals of prehistoric piranha into Lake Victoria, local sheriff Julie Forester (Shue) tries in vain to persuade several thousand Spring Break revellers to quit their aquatic hedonism before they become fish food. Meanwhile, her son Jake (McQueen) has been lured onto a boat by slimeball porn director Derrick (O’Connell) and busty, bikini-clad ‘star’ Danni (British ‘glamour model’ Brook). Also aboard is nice girl Kelly (Szohr), on whom Jake has a crush. But once the fishy feeding frenzy starts, it’s human flesh that’s on the menu.
Aja serves up the tongue-in-cheek thrills, CGI-enhanced gore and gratuitous nudity with such relish that this may prove to be the summer’s break-out horror hit. There are also nice cameos from Richard Dreyfuss, reprising his Jaws role, and Hostel director Eli Roth, who completely loses his head after hosting a wet T-shirt contest. Guilty pleasure? Guilty as charged.

version.name: The Burning Plain
version.plot: Not negligible, but disappointing movie from the writer of Babel
version.review:
Having split from director Alejandro González Iñárritu after Babel, screenwriter Guillermo Arriaga’s first directorial outing is more of the same – only less so. As a tangled story criss-crosses the US-Mexican border, Arriaga’s jigsaw-puzzle writing reveals links between Oregon restaurant manager Charlize Theron, frustrated New Mexico housewife Kim Basinger’s troubled relationship with her daughter, and the fate of a Mexican girl who’s seen her crop-dusting father crash his plane.
No surprise it all fits together in the end, to tell a tale of the ripple effect of sundry pressure-cooker decisions, though Arriaga gives the game away too early. The performances are hard to fault, but the direction leaves the movie lacking juice and us thinking a clunky chain of events has been jazzed up by the mosaic-style construction. Not negligible, but disappointing.

version.name: Going the Distance
version.plot: Pleasantly surprising romantic comedy with Drew Barrymore and Justin Long
version.review:
A pleasant surprise, Going the Distance is the first romantic comedy that seems expressly geared for the current recession. It paints a surprisingly serious portrait of two people, Stanford journalism student Erin (Barrymore) and dissatisfied NYC record promoter Garrett (Long). Before Erin leaves New York for California the two fall for each other, and they proceed from the wide-eyed notion that their long-distance relationship might work.
What gives this film an edge is the suspense over whether their love really can conquer career and ambition – as well as the acknowledgment that it might not. If this makes Going the Distance potentially notable, none of it would make it entertaining if the movie weren’t funny – and it is, thanks to Garrett’s oversharing roommate and especially Applegate, who is hilarious as Erin’s OCD sister on the Left Coast. The leads have great chemistry (as one might suspect from a reported on-again, off-again couple), but part of what’s refreshing about this film is that their chemistry is beside the point.

version.name: Solomon Kane
version.plot: Violent Lord of the Rings-style fantasy is fused with savage reality
version.review:
Scarred and tattooed, the swashbuckling hero of this dark sword and sorcery movie bears the marks of his brutal life like stigmata; the impression left by British writer-director Michael J Bassett’s monstrously entertaining action-adventure is just as indelible. Rather than adapt one of the Savage Tales of Solomon Kane written by Conan the Barbarian creator Robert E Howard, Bassett has created a character-driven yet action-packed ‘origins’ story, one that traces his hero’s journey from bloodthirsty pirate through peaceful pilgrim to conflicted Puritan avenger, complete with cape, distinctive black hat, pistols and swords.
James Purefoy is charismatic as Kane, who, escaping the clutches of a soul-sucking demon, renounces violence. But when the Puritan family he befriends is slaughtered by the sorcerer Malachi’s disfigured henchman, he takes up the sword again, vowing to rescue their enslaved daughter. Grounded in a believable sixteenth-century English milieu that sharpens rather than blunts its fantastical edge, the film’s epic vision bears comparison with the Lord of the Rings trilogy, its imaginative supernatural elements confidently fused with a savage reality.

version.name: The Cry of the Owl
version.plot: This pyschological thriller is more twisted than the average
version.review: This pyschological thriller is more twisted than the average. Jenny, the object of a stalker’s obsession and whose boyfriend goes missing, is played by Julia Stiles, whose role is an interesting departure from the largely undemanding roles in which she is usually cast.

version.name: You Again
version.plot: Marital comedy with a stellar female cast and plenty of catfighting
version.review: PR whizz Marni returns home for her older brother’s wedding to discover he’s planning to marry her high-school nemesis, who’s conveniently forgotten all the rotten things she did way back when. As Marni sets about trying to expose his fiancée, in bursts the bride’s jet-setting aunt, and Marni’s not-so-jet-setting mum comes face to face with her own high-school rival. Naturally, it’s several handbags at dawn.

version.name: The Switch
version.plot: Jenifer Aniston is 40, broody and single. Let the jokes begin...
version.review:
She’s 40, broody and single, so TV production assistant Jennifer Aniston decides to have a child via a sperm donor. As the title pretty much gives away, complications with two different helpings of man-seed lie ahead. But what the title and marketing don’t tell you is that Aniston is essentially a secondary character.
The focus is actually on her unattached best friend, played by Jason Bateman, and his discovery that he may not be much of a lover, but he’s a great father. Curiously, he comes on like a latter-day Tony Randall, charming yet neurotic. Bateman’s performance – as a broker shedding his anxious reserve when it’s his turn to look after Aniston’s melancholy little boy (Robinson, a real discovery) – is funny, touching and observed in micro-detail throughout.
Like directing duo Josh Gordon and Will Speck’s 2007 ice-skating frolic Blades of Glory, the film consequently dangles uneasily between quirky and mainstream. The directors treat the central switcheroo narrative like the chore it is and can do little with the grinding plot mechanics, which ultimately turn Aniston and her donor-of-choice (Patrick Wilson) into cardboard cyphers.
When Bateman and Robinson are on screen, though, it’s a different movie, striking a witty note of nervy authenticity as two misfit males from different generations care and share together. With Jeff Goldblum chiming in usefully as Bateman’s sardonic boss, there’s much to enjoy, if not quite enough to disguise the film’s essential awkwardness in trying to cover too many bases.

version.name: Fly Me to the Moon
version.plot: First animated movie created exclusively to be shown in 3D cinemas
version.review: The first animated movie created exclusively to be shown in 3D cinemas arrives in the Middle Easttwo years after its original release. Fly Me to the Moon follows Nat (Gagnon), IQ (Bolden) and Scooter (Gore) as houseflies with a mission: they decide to hitch a ride to the moon with the Apollo 11 space team. Once in orbit, they solve a technical glitch while Nat’s grandpa averts disaster in mission control by thwarting the plans of a Russian infiltrator, Yegor. It’s all very superficial, but endurable in the main, even though it can’t resist that old chestnut of painting the Russians as baddies. While it may not teach sprogs anything about insects – these ones have human eyes and four limbs – director Ben Stassen has made a fair fist of portraying the Apollo mission with some accuracy.

version.name: Resident Evil: Afterlife
version.plot: Globe-trotting sequel to the popular video game adaptation
version.review:
You all know Alice (Jovovich), the luscious butt-kicker who’s out to bring down the evil Umbrella corporation in an undead-infested future. In this latest incarnation of the Resident Evil franchise, we follow her as she searches for the mythical, humans-only haven known as Arcadia, which takes her from Japan to Alaska and finally to Los Angeles, where she holes up with several other pieces of zombie bait.
Director Paul WS Anderson makes often-inspiring use of the 3D effects, though he never quite tops the opening Shibuya Crossing bloodbath – a sanguine B-side to the pickpocket finale of Sparrow, Johnnie To’s 2008 crime-cinema gem.

version.name: Mesrine: Public Enemy No. 1
version.plot: While Mesrine: Death Instinct chronicled the ascendancy of Vincent Cassel’s cocksure French crim
version.review: While Mesrine: Death Instinct chronicled the ascendancy of Vincent Cassel’s cocksure French crim, Jacques Mesrine, this second chapter ditches the mechanics of his life story in favour of a ruminative, often unsympathetic inspection of his contradictory character traits. The early stages hint at a Heat-like battle of wits between Mesrine and tireless police commissioner Broussard (Olivier Gourmet), but a last-minute escape from justice puts the spotlight back on Cassel. Unlike its more lively predecessor, this offering is more interested in dissecting the criminal mindset and proposes the theory that the acts of a felon prevent him or her from being able to maintain logical personal and political ideals. In one scene, Mesrine violently forces a family to hide him from the cops, the next minute, he’s handing over loot in return for their services.

version.name: The Greatest
version.plot: Shana Feste’s shameless sucker-punch of a drama
version.review: Shana Feste’s shameless sucker-punch of a drama, which romps all over the emotional messiness of mourning like a frenetic feline on a catnip-covered floor, is a straight up grief-fest. After the film’s martyr – Aaron Johnson’s jockish, jocular Bennett – perishes in a car accident before the opening credits, the movie lays out how each of the teen’s family members process their loss. Mum (Susan Sarandon) breaks down into a hyperactive, hysterical bundle of nerves; Dad (Pierce Brosnan) shuts down entirely; and the younger brother (Johnny Simmons), a former substance abuser, simply stares numbly off into space. And then the screaming – and crying, and oh-the-humanity Oscar baiting – starts in earnest. Given that Sarandon played this same role so sublimely before in Moonlight Mile, her devolution into theatrical gnashing of teeth is particularly disappointing, but no one – not Brosnan’s patriarch nor Mulligan’s waif – comes out of this pity party unscathed.

version.name: The Combination
version.plot: This critically acclaimed, yet under-the-radar Aussie effort charts the difficult relations between the Lebanese-Australian and Anglo-Australian
version.review: This critically acclaimed, yet under-the-radar Aussie effort charts the difficult relations between the Lebanese-Australian and Anglo-Australian communities in western Sydney, based on the real-life experiences of lead actor George Basha.

version.name: Nothing But the Truth
version.plot: Reporter Rachel Armstrong (Kate Beckinsale) breaks an explosive story
version.review:
Reporter Rachel Armstrong (Kate Beckinsale) breaks an explosive story in her Washington daily paper revealing the identity of an undercover CIA agent and her role in the investigation of a plot to assassinate the President of the United States. As a result of the ensuing chaos, Armstrong is hauled in front of a grand jury by Federal prosecutor Patton Dubois (Matt Dillon), who demands to know who her source is.
After consistently refusing to divulge the name of her informer, Armstrong is sent to prison for contempt of court, from where her relationship with both her husband (David Schwimmer) and young son Timmy (Preston Bailey) decline. A dip in the film’s pace while its protagonist resides behind bars is almost too much to bear, but persevere and the story picks up again when the audience is led to believe she will finally reveal her source. She doesn’t – and so to another two years in prison (snore) – but at least we find out who it is.

version.name: Takers
version.plot: Enthralling action thriller with Matt Dillon and Idris Elba
version.review:
The Wire’s Idris Elba heads a West Coast posse of sharp-dressed kleptos who do one big job a year and nightclub it the other 364. Matt Dillon is the fuzz on their tail, a grizzled obsessive in love with his job and neglectful of his family.
It’s obvious that the dung will soon pelt the spinning chopper blades; in terms of plot, Takers is as derivative as a direct-to-video quickie. Yet for all its faux Michael Mann-isms, the film is still enthralling. Director John Luessenhop’s aggressive approach to action scenes is frequently inspired, especially the parkour-peppered foot chase. And the casting, from lead roles to supporting, is uniformly terrific: it’s a pleasure to see the underutilised Marianne Jean-Baptiste (of Mike Leigh’s Secrets & Lies) steal scenes as Elba’s drug-addict sis.

version.name: Eat Pray Love
version.plot: Book-inspired romance with Julia Roberts and Billy Crudup
version.review:
This is expert pop-psychology; plates of pasta will be consumed in Rome (to nourish a wounded heart); the soul will be tended in an Indian ashram; and romance will flourish in Bali. In the context of summer’s other lunkheaded fantasies, is that really so offensive?
Julia Roberts produces a gloriously complex performance – to our eyes, her best. She has a movie star’s size, which she constantly underplays, curling into balls of insecurity and lifting her glass in tear-rimmed ruefulness. Oh, to have Julia’s choices: crushed ex-husband Billy Crudup, cute yogi James Franco, the Bali-dwelling Javier Bardem. The movie is completely aware of its own riches; it fills up your plate and dares you not to eat.

version.name: The Boys Are Back
version.plot: Tearful Clive Owen drama about a father-son relationship
version.review:
Hankies at the ready, folks. Bearing similarities to 2007’s And When Did You Last See Your Father?, this is a moving examination of father-son relations adapted from a memoir. Joe (Clive Owen) is a British sports journalist who is living in Australia and must renew his relationship with his six-year-old son Artie (Nicholas McAnulty) when his wife Katy (Laura Fraser) dies suddenly from cancer.
Still grieving, Joe takes a laissez-faire approach to parenting (he calls it ‘just say yes’) as he tries to juggle work with child-rearing, while maintaining relations with a difficult mother-in-law and repair his bond with Harry (George MacKay), a teenage son from a previous marriage. ‘The moment you think you’re… sorted is the moment it all starts falling apart,’ says Owen’s downbeat but sympathetic voiceover.
It may sound sentimental, but director Scott Hicks (Shine) mostly avoids soppiness, even if he’s not afraid to make the odd plea for empathy. Hicks is well served by an endearing Owen, whose performance ranks as one of his best, and beautiful photography from rising Aussie Greig Fraser. Hicks’s style is straightforward and unfussy – a description you could apply to this big-hearted film as a whole.

movie.name: Legend of the Guardians: The Owls of Ga'Hoole

version.name: Legend of the Guardians: The Owls of Ga'Hoole
version.plot: The heroic adventures of owls who battle wearing armour
version.review:
Every studio exec in Hollywood has spent the past five years scouring the children’s lit catalogue for the next Harry Potter. Along the way, some good fantasy books have been turned into muddled movies (The Golden Compass, The Chronicles of Narnia, Percy Jackson & the Olympians). Kathryn Lasky’s Guardians of Ga’Hoole books, about the heroic adventures of owls who battle wearing armour, is an obvious candidate for adaptation. A young hero is separated from his family, experiences some bad things, undertakes an epic journey and learns important life lessons. It writes itself. The fact that the heroes are, you know, owls, with sorely limited facial expressions… well, that’s just a challenge for the digital animators.
Director Zack Snyder tackles the movie with the same plodding bombast he delivered in 300. He’s also overly fond of the swooping mobile camera, which gives owl flight a vertiginous feeling, but also makes the film feel like a boat ride on a rather stormy night. The plot moves along in a fashion that will probably satisfy the target audience (the under 13s), but it’s a grind for anyone who knows their way around the fantasy tropes.

version.name: Devil
version.plot: Silly horror film from the mind of M Night Shyamalan
version.review:
After Lady in the Water, The Happening and especially The Last Airbender, one would have thought any sane production company would want to keep M Night Shyamalan’s name as far away as possible from their new product. And yet here comes Devil, the first instalment in the worryingly titled ‘Night Chronicles’, a series of standalone projects conceived – if not actually written and directed – by the one-time golden boy of mainstream Hollywood horror.
The setup is simple: it’s the wrath of Satan… in a lift. Five strangers get stuck in an elevator. They start dying; the religious lift operator realises each has a dark secret and Beelzebub has come to claim their souls.
Despite his staunchly Catholic education, Shyamalan has kept his own movies largely free of religious dogma. But Devil’s subject matter leaves no such room for obfuscation: this movie is loaded with damnation, and is snarkily dismissive of non-believers. It’s not a bad film, just a silly, unconvincing one: entertaining enough in its way, but crude, inert and quickly forgotten.

version.name: The Maiden Heist
version.plot: A weaker-than-average offering from a high-ranking cast, this harmless caper makes for undemanding watching
version.review: A weaker-than-average offering from a high-ranking cast, this harmless caper makes for undemanding watching. Quite why anyone would accept a script based around the attempts of three museum guards to save their favourite pieces from being sold to the Danes is perhaps beyond convincing explanation. Though Roger (Christopher Walken) Charles (Morgan Freeman) and George (William H Macy) are mere acquaintances at the beginning of the film, they come together to form an unlikely alliance in order to steal the works of art they have each become most attached to. The film missed out on a theatrical release overseas after the bankruptcy of its distributor, Yari Film Group, going straight to DVD, but will perhaps be just the ticket for cinema-goers who have exhausted all options this summer.

version.name: Fake Identity
version.plot: Incredible as it sounds, Val Kilmer was once big business in Hollywood
version.review: Incredible as it sounds, Val Kilmer was once big business in Hollywood, cracking up audiences in Top Secret, proving his acting credentials as Jim Morrison in The Doors and even, despite being the wrong side of chubby, putting in a strong ‘actor number four’ slot in Heat. But that’s where the magic ends – actually it ended with The Saint – and as such we’re not holding much faith in this ’80s thriller, set (and filmed) in Bulgaria. Anecdotal evidence suggests it’s not as bad as you think, but history isn’t on Val’s side.

version.name: Ruslan
version.plot: Steven Seagal stars as former Russian mobster-turned-writer Ruslan Drachev in this action flick
version.review: Steven Seagal stars as former Russian mobster-turned-writer Ruslan Drachev in this action flick, originally released under the title Driven to Kill, which went straight to DVD in the US. That’s probably an indication of the standard of movie you can expect if you sit through this.

version.name: The Town
version.plot: This is a slick but inert cops ’n’ robbers yarn from Ben Affleck
version.review:
This is a slick but inert cops ’n’ robbers yarn from Ben Affleck (with his director-writer-star hat on) that feels all but indistinguishable from the thousands of similar films that have blazed a trail before it. Sporting a neat crew cut and a nice line in ‘Boston’-emblazoned tracksuits, Affleck is Doug, the conflicted leader of a rubber-masked wrecking crew who take down banks on behalf of kingpin (and florist!) Pete Postlethwaite. Doug wants to take his loot and make a break for Florida. But Pete has dirt on him.
You’d hazard from this and his previous directorial effort, Gone Baby Gone, that Affleck counts Michael Mann and Sidney Lumet among his muses. You’d also guess from the film’s slickly calculated pacing and surfeit of soulful heart-to-hearts that he has a fondness for the TV work of David Simon, notably The Wire. Yet despite the grubby locations in the Bostonian crime-hub of Charlestown, the film’s credibility feels severely hamstrung by the fact that even though the robbers are armed and dangerous, too much effort is made to ensure us that it’s never nice-guy Affleck who’s pulling the trigger.

version.name: Scott Pilgrim vs. the World
version.plot: Scott Pilgrim trades in the messy lives of twentysomething slackers
version.review:
Scott Pilgrim vs the World might be a US studio movie and have cost more than three times the combined budgets of Hot Fuzz and Shaun of the Dead, but for British director Edgar Wright it’s no huge leap from Spaced, the ’90s TV series that made his name. Like Spaced, Scott Pilgrim trades in the messy lives of twentysomething slackers and springs from the world of the comic. The two also share a similar relationship to realism and fantasy: what we get are down-to-earth observations on everyday lives explained with wild flights of visual and narrative fancy.
Whether you like or just admire Scott Pilgrim will probably rest with how you feel about Scott, as played by Hollywood’s favourite nerd, Michael Cera. Scott is the 22-year-old jobless bass player in a garage band called Sex Bob-omb; it’s the kind of role that Cera regularly plays. But he’s also likeable, adorable at times, and free of the super-cool jive-talking that mars films such as Juno. It means that when the frosty, unreachable Ramona Flowers (Winstead) tumbles into his life, we’re already running along with him.
Scott Pilgrim feels like Ghost World in its honouring of young people with spikey, interesting personalities. There are hints of Woody Allen in its navel-gazing, and a dash of The Matrix in its sneaky affection for pyrotechnics. It could have been a noisy, flashy mess, but luckily it has heart, which makes it feel fun and unique, and more like a lo-fi, endearing mess instead.

version.name: The Hole
version.plot: For the first hour of this haphazard 3D adventure, it feels as though director Joe ‘the subversive Spielberg’ Dante has never been away
version.review:
For the first hour of this haphazard 3D adventure, it feels as though director Joe ‘the subversive Spielberg’ Dante has never been away: here come the lovingly written kids from Explorers, moving into the white-picket American fairyland of The ’Burbs and promptly being terrorised by mystical, malevolent beings à la Gremlins. Said supernatural critters emanate from the mysterious, padlocked, seemingly bottomless pit beneath the boys’ new house, and Dante plays the early scenes perfectly, racking up the clammy dread without tipping over into outright nastiness.
But somewhere along the way, the tension dissipates: once the somewhat pedestrian truth is revealed, there’s nowhere for the film to go. Dante pulls off a visually bold, thematically bleak finale, inspired equally by his own berserk Twilight Zone: The Movie segment, but never quite claws back the sustained suspense of the superb early sequences. Nevertheless, it’s good to welcome back one of the undisputed masters of modern genre cinema – and adventurous kids will love it.

version.name: Vampires Suck
version.plot: Vampire flick from the team behind Date Movie, Epic Movie and Meet the Spartans
version.review: With Date Movie, Epic Movie and Meet the Spartans on their résumés, directors Jason Friedberg and Aaron Seltzer have proved their expertise at sucking. Their latest – a spoof of the Twilight saga – does nothing to alter that reputation. Aimed primarily at those invested in Team Jacob versus Team Edward, it’s a sloppy collection of parodic gags that are below bottom-of-the-barrel. You think those children of the night are lifeless? This movie redefines the concept.

version.name: As Good as Dead
version.plot: Unintentionally uproarious psycho-thriller with Andie MacDowell
version.review: Three rising stars of 1989 hit career rock-bottom in director Jonathan Mossek’s unintentionally uproarious psycho-thriller, in which an NYC photojournalist (Elwes) is kidnapped by avenging white supremacists. There’s some camp pleasure in watching Frank Whaley and Andie MacDowell – possibly the least threatening humans in history – sport neck tattoos and menace a bloated Elwes. But it’s hardly worth slogging through the unexplained bondage and a so-bombastic-it-seems-sarcastic score, only to be rewarded with a plea for tolerance that’s both insincere and inept.

version.name: Stone
version.plot: Original and suspenseful thriller with Robert De Niro and Edward Norton
version.review:
A quick-talking convict up for parole (Norton) is willing to do anything to get his strict case officer (De Niro) to let him out – including faux-finding religion and using his comely wife (Jovovich) to seduce the sad-sack officer. Surely we’ve already seen this movie, right? But director John Curran lets viewers know early on that he couldn’t give two hoots about making a typical who’s-conning-who thriller. This character-driven drama offers something far more complex, cracked and unique for a US movie boasting big-name stars: an unblinking glare into the abyss. Neither the white-noise soundtrack nor Norton’s rusty-door Detroit accent can drown out the keening pitch of the movie’s central irony – why does one ‘bad’ man have a genuine epiphany, while a ‘good’ one goes into a moral freefall?
This is the best work De Niro has done in a decade, a triumph of real, honest acting; you not only forget you’re watching an icon, you feel as if you’re truly witnessing someone burdened with decades of emotional baggage crumble before your eyes.

version.name: Alpha and Omega
version.plot: Lionsgate’s drab, anthropomorphic animal saga is a dog in wolf’s clothing
version.review:
A dog in wolf’s clothing, Lionsgate’s drab, anthropomorphic animal saga does little more than reconfirm the preeminence of Pixar. Two wolves – the happy-go-lucky omega, Humphrey (Long), and the beautiful alpha, Kate (Panettiere) – are destined to bay at the moon together. Yet ingrained intolerance stands in their way, as natural law states that their disparate kinds shan’t mix. Rather, Humphrey is required to live the life of a jovial clown; as the new leader, Kate is expected to unite the pack with starving Eastern wolves via an arranged marriage to a howl-impaired athletic stud (Carmack).
Still, once these would-be lovebirds are shot with tranquilisers and relocated from Canada to Idaho – thus initiating a joint odyssey back home – they come together because, hey, opposites attract! It’s a pity there are no sparks in their amour, nor in the story’s humourless supporting characters (specifically, a goose who plays golf and hates cupcakes) and the torpid voice work from all involved, including, sadly, the late Dennis Hopper. The fact that the movie’s middling animation is drenched in 3D running-and-jumping effects doesn’t help one bit, proving that today’s buzzword technology remains a tool best suited for those gimmicky moments when objects are hurtling at the viewer.

version.name: Let Me In
version.plot: English remake of a cult Vampire movie actually improves on the original
version.review:
Vampire movies aren’t going away any time soon, and Sweden’s Let the Right One In, an elegant tale of teenage alienation and bloodsucking, has made the resurgence that much easier to stomach. So let’s hear it for the oldest demon in the book: Hollywood remakers. You’d think these parasites would have turned this intimate foreign property into a gory mess. But the new Let Me In does more than merely preserve the original’s mood; it actually improves on it.
The question will invariably be asked: was an English-language version needed? One might have challenged 1920s producer Carl Laemmle Jr on the same grounds after he saw Murnau’s Nosferatu; he savoured the details, and Dracula was the result.

version.name: Whatever Works
version.plot: Many actors have played the Woody Allen role in Woody Allen movies besides Woody Allen, and with mixed success
version.review:
Many actors have played the Woody Allen role in Woody Allen movies besides Woody Allen, and with mixed success: for every John Cusack in Bullets Over Broadway, there’s a Kenneth Branagh in Celebrity. In Allen’s latest film, Larry David assumes the role of sharply observant, neurotically indignant, endearingly curmudgeonly nebbish, and as casting it’s a qualified success: David brings a spiky sense of mischief that sidesteps self-pity, but he remains so aloof from the action that it’s hard to engage emotionally.
A former physicist and Nobel near-miss, Boris Yelnikoff (David) leaps from a window in despair at his futile existence but survives. Before long, he’s shacked up downtown with Melody (Evan Rachel Wood), a ditzy waif from Mississippi whose artless wonder threatens to chip away at his ingrained misanthropy.
The broadness of the antic characters Allen sends across Boris’s path and the crises to which they fall subject are too exaggerated to engage as drama, and those uncomfortable with Allen’s tendency to pair nubile girls with ageing men will find little relief. But for all its wobbles, Whatever Works is rooted in an agreeable sensibility: life favours fate over luck, so grab whatever chances of happiness come your way.

version.name: Earth
version.plot: This feature-length version of the popular British documentary series follows the migratory paths of the polar bear
version.review: This feature-length version of the popular British documentary series follows the migratory paths of the polar bear, the African bush elephant and the humpback whale, from the North Pole in January to the South in December. A colourful supporting cast features animals from cheetahs to ducklings, but there’s an uncomfortable message for viewers about the precarious situation in which we’re placing each of these species with global warming.

version.name: Shanghai
version.plot: A decade in the making, this period thriller set during World War II sees US secret agent Paul Soames (Cusack) head to Shanghai to investigate the murder of a close friend
version.review: A decade in the making, this period thriller set during World War II sees US secret agent Paul Soames (Cusack) head to Shanghai to investigate the murder of a close friend. His enquiries lead him further and further into the city’s criminal underworld, where he becomes involved with Anna Lan-Ting (Li) the wife of his primary suspect, Chinese gangster Anthony Lan-Ting (Yun-Fat). It soon becomes apparent that national loyalties are being traded fast and loose for those of the heart.

version.name: Icarus
version.plot: Also known as Dolph Lundgren is the Killing Machine
version.review: Also known as Dolph Lundgren is the Killing Machine, this action romp directed by the man himself was released theatrically in LA for just one week – a fact that sees our expectations for this film substantially lowered. A Soviet-trained assassin based in America attempts to distance himself from his murderous past and get reacquainted with his wife and daughter, but there are old forces who are not so willing to let him embrace such a future. This is not the stuff of Oscars.

version.name: The Social Network
version.plot: A mischievous, scaremongering tale about the origins of Facebook
version.review:
A mischievous, scaremongering tale about the origins of Facebook, this film makes its case instantly that founder Mark Zuckerberg is a social disaster, and sticks to that line as it moves from the college dorms of Massachusetts to the hip offices of California. We meet Zuckerberg (Eisenberg) as he develops various sites until he hits on TheFacebook.com, which he runs with friend Eduardo Saverin (Garfield), who is the bridge between Zuckerberg and Harvard’s exclusive student clubs – a world from which he feels bitterly excluded. As Facebook grows, Zuckerberg moves to California, seduced by the charms of Napster’s founder, Sean Parker (Timberlake, smart casting), who offers Zuckerberg informal membership of a world of investors by day and parties by night.
The Social Network sticks the knife into Zuckerberg and milks for all it’s worth the irony of a disconnected soul connecting the world. But Fincher and Sorkin never let us forget that we’re complicit in their story (or at least 500 million of us are).

version.name: Paranormal Activity 2
version.plot: Big budget sequel to the terrifying cult horror hit
version.review:
It may have cost 200 times more than Oren Peli’s US$15,000 original, but it’s barely one tenth as scary. A more appropriate title would have been Paranormal Inactivity Too. The alleged ‘found’ footage is prefaced by a title reading, ‘60 hours before the death of Micah Sloat’ – Sloat being the male character whose demise marked the climax of the first film.
After their home is trashed, Christy persuades her husband to install CCTV in the house and garden. These cameras then show us evidence of demonic (in)activity, capturing the mysterious opening of doors, the aimless nocturnal meanderings of the robotic swimming pool cleaner, and the spooked behaviour of the family dog. The less said about Martine, the stereotyped superstitious Mexican maid, the better: her sole function is to provide patronising comic relief by wafting incense about the house, while rambling incoherently in Spanish about the spirits.

version.name: Black Death
version.plot: Set during the plague of 1348, Christopher Smith’s best film to date is a tale of fundamentalist Christianity
version.review:
Set during the plague of 1348, Christopher Smith’s best film to date is a tale of fundamentalist Christianity, fearful superstition and paganism. Based on a fluid, intelligent screenplay by Dario Poloni, it marks Smith out as Britain’s most talented, least appreciated genre filmmaker.
After persuading his secret lover to flee their plague-ravaged town, doubting novice monk Osmund (Redmayne) joins the bishop’s devout military envoy, Ulric (Bean) on an expedition to a remote village. This village has mysteriously been spared the pestilence and is rumoured to be a hotbed of pagan beliefs and necromancy. Dragging behind them a huge wooden torture device, Ulric and his men are guided by Osmund through the woods and marshes, encountering bandits and witch-burning locals en route. Beneath the village’s placid surface is a roiling pit of religious duplicity and moral decay.
The ruthless Ulric represents the official church, yet his zealotry prompts the Abbot (Warner) to remark: ‘That man is more dangerous than the pestilence itself.’

version.name: Spread
version.plot: Lame attempt to update Breakfast at Tiffany’s for the Twitter generation
version.review: How charming is Ashton Kutcher? The answer to this question has a direct bearing on your enjoyment of Spread, an ego-massaging vehicle for the party-hopping Angeleno that, for its first half, feels like an extended episode of his US ad campaign for Canon Coolpix (check it out on YouTube). As a smug, penniless gigolo who trades sex for food and lodging – until he inevitably falls for his female equivalent (Levieva) – Kutcher, with the help of director David Mackenize, lamely tries to update Breakfast at Tiffany’s for the Twitter generation. Too bad Truman Capote is not around for rewrites.

version.name: Ninja
version.plot: American martial arts film holds few surprises or thrills
version.review: Little is known about this action film, apart from this: an American studying the art of ninjutsu in Japan is told to return to the States by the Sensei. Why? To protect a chest which holds a few ancient weapons – apparently a ‘lethal mission’.

version.name: Due Date
version.plot: From the outset, Due Date doesn’t sound like a box-office winner
version.review: From the outset, Due Date doesn’t sound like a box-office winner – a man rushing to hospital to witness the birth of his child – but thanks to Sherlock Holmes and his recent Iron Man endeavours, Downey Jr has proved himself a riveting and thoroughly entertaining motormouth. Pair him with Zach Galifianakis (anticipating the latter’s usual brand of surreal humour) and this man-on-a-mission road movie, directed by The Hangover’s Todd Phillips, could be a surprising seasonal hit.

version.name: Secretariat
version.plot: A family entertainment that the Brady Bunch would have enjoyed
version.review:
A family entertainment that the Brady Bunch would have enjoyed (if not actually starred in), Disney’s real-life horse story, about the 1973 Triple Crown winner, is a solid shot.
Diane Lane’s primly perfect Penny Chenery has guts enough to stand up to her lawyer hubby and the sexist Virginia businessmen who would rather she sell her daddy’s stable. She’s got a special feeling about one newborn colt, wobbling around adorably on stalky legs only moments after vacating the womb.
But whoa, hold on just a second: Penny will require the help of a rascally, strange-hat-wearing genius of a trainer (Malkovich), an intuitive, respectful horse groom and even her hippy kids, who inspire her to stand up for what she believes, gosh darn it. At one point, suspicion arises that there’s not enough of a story here for an actual movie, but Lane, experiencing her career heyday, is sweet enough to have you rooting for her, even if her journey to the winner’s circle is an odds-on favourite.

version.name: Leaves of Grass
version.plot: Edward Norton's genre-defying comedy is a mostly mirthless affair
version.review:
A dumb comedy out to prove its genre-defying smarts, Leaves of Grass is a mostly mirthless affair; not even the sight of Edward Norton portraying twins tickles as it should. Whether he’s expounding on Socrates as urbane East Coast classics professor Bill Kincaid or doing Cletus-the-slack-jawed-yokel shtick as his pot-growing Oklahoman bro, Brady, it’s clear he’s playing tics as opposed to creating people. Belly laughs might not be what writer-director Tim Blake Nelson is after, of course.
Sprinkled in with the regional comic shenanigans (the film is mostly set in and around Tulsa) are 15 other movies – a drug thriller, a love story and a family drama among them. The best of these features Keri Russell as the lady-love that Bill takes up with after making an impromptu journey west for his brother’s supposed funeral. It would be overly polite to call this a pale shadow of the tone-shifting Coen brothers farces from which Nelson – who co-starred in O Brother, Where Art Thou? – is taking his cues. It’s a real downer.

version.name: Saw 7
version.plot: Seventh and (allegedly) final instalment in the Saw series. In 3D
version.review:
Watching the seventh and (allegedly) final instalment in the Saw series is like pulling your own teeth out, while watching yourself on a giant 3D screen. A series of groups filled with Jigsaw survivors has coalesced around Bobby Dagen (Flanery), a publicity-hungry author whose book detailing his own ordeal at the hands of the puppet-master is a bestseller. But the inheritor of Jigsaw’s mantle, corrupt detective Mark Hoffman (Mandylor), knows Bobby’s secret; he never was a victim – but that’s about to change.
The set-piece torture scenes are elaborately dull and the 3D images add nothing but another level of fuzziness. For completist fans, the one reason to see the series through to its conclusion is an answer to the question: What happened to Dr Gordon (Elwes), who we last saw crawling away at the end of the first film, his leg sawn off above the ankle? Other than that, there’s nothing new, and there’s far too much that’s old and past its smell-by date.
A nasty whiff of desperation hangs over the whole enterprise.

version.name: Deadline
version.plot: Spooky thriller with the late Brittany Murphy
version.review: A screenwriter recovering from a recent breakdown (the late Murphy) takes up residence at an abandoned house, where she hopes she’ll find the peace and quiet she needs to finish a screenplay on time. As is the way with abandoned houses, all is not as it seems, and strange happenings see her turn sleuth.

version.name: Unstoppable
version.plot: Director Tony Scott returns with Denzel Washington as his leading man
version.review: Director Tony Scott returns with Denzel Washington as his leading man in this action adventure about a runaway train carrying a haul of dangerous chemicals that’s heading towards a big city. In a storyline not altogether dissimilar to The Taking of Pelham 123 (of which, surprise, surprise, Scott was a producer), Washington plays a veteran locomotive engineer tasked with saving the city, only this time he has a young conductor sidekick (Pine) along for the ride.

version.name: Closing the Ring
version.plot: Military drama directed by 84-year-old Richard Attenborough
version.review:
At 84, director Richard Attenborough has a new film, energised presumably by an endearing tale with strong appeal for the more mature viewer. Michigan, 1991, and a World War II flyer goes to his grave after years of an empty marriage, leaving widow MacLaine with some explaining to do to bristling daughter Campbell. Meanwhile, in Belfast, treasure hunters (Michael McCann and Pete Postlethwaite) risk the wrath of the IRA by excavating a site where a US bomber went down during the war, discovering a ring which could link destinies on both sides of the Atlantic.
Although fortunes unfold at a pace unhurried by today’s standards, and the melodramatic final reel flirts with incredulity, the film’s affirmation that it’s never too late to set lives in order carries a ruminative emotional charge. While MacLaine’s indomitable form is something to see, the story’s awkward contrivances prove insurmountable. With all the will in the world, this is a mere footnote to Attenborough’s filmography.

version.name: Megamind
version.plot: Animated superhero comedy with Will Ferrel and Brad Pitt
version.review:
By now, pretty much everyone is hip to the fact that superheroes are a snooze; supervillains are where the real action is. Megamind screenwriters Alan J Schoolcraft and Brent Simons know that Ferrell is their strongest card, and they have shaped the script to allow for a lot of rapid-fire jokes perfectly suited to his particular style.
We’ve grown pretty tired of this sort of zinger stuff of late, because so often it’s not done all that well, and the topical references are a lazy substitute for good plotting. But Megamind works remarkably well because the jokes about superheroes are above-average stuff, on par with The Incredibles, and the script has a well-structured plot with some twists (one, alas, blown by the film’s ad campaign).
Ferrell’s Megamind is an evil genius who clearly loves the endless battles with smug good guy Metro Man (Pitt). But it’s only after Metro Man is out of the picture that Megamind realises he needs a good yin to his evil yang; Fey provides solid voice support as a tough reporter.
It should be noted that the film makes reasonably effective use of 3D, but we’re betting that it would work perfectly well in 2D, so feel free to economise. The real added dimensions here are in the script.

version.name: Red
version.plot: Boisterous knockabout action comedy with Bruce Willis
version.review: Pension-age suburbanite Frank Moses (Willis) wakes up to a volley of fire from masked hitmen; as he deals with them one by one, he realises his retirement is going to take a violent detour. The title stands for ‘retired, extremely dangerous’, and this knockabout action comedy is a boisterous, getting-the-band-back-together movie as Frank assembles a crew of trigger-happy oldsters (John Malkovich, Morgan Freeman, Helen Mirren, Brian Cox) to uncover why his distinguished, black-ops past is coming back to haunt him. It’s a charming mess, rescued by the knowing gusto of the acting. Beneath its light exterior is not only a neat, if unsubtle, political undercurrent, but a rebellious streak about how the allure of firing an RPG outweighs the prospect of retirement.

movie.name: Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows: Part 1

version.name: Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows: Part 1
version.plot: Is the seventh installment of the Harry Potter series any good?
version.review:
Anyone who complained that the previous episode in the ‘Harry Potter’ saga felt too much like scene-setting for the final showdown will be equally disappointed with ‘Deathly Hallows Part 1’. A film with no beginning and no end but a whole lot of expository middle, this is the least satisfying instalment in the series since Chris Columbus folded up his director’s chair.
Bill Nighy’s dour, dandified Minister of Magic sets the tone with a barbed speech bemoaning the state of the magical nation: murders, disappearances and raids are becoming commonplace and no one, it seems, is safe. Least of all our bespectacled hero, who bids farewell to the suburbia of his youth before being whisked away in the film’s only outright action sequence, a dizzying high-speed flying-bike chase through the Dartford tunnel.
The ensuing half hour is business as usual: an entertaining balance of sorcery, slapstick and sweetness, enlivened by a handful of scary scenes and a surprisingly sadistic streak of black humour. But once the kids decide to break out on their own, setting off across the shattered English countryside on the trail of the four remaining shards of the Dark Lord Voldemort’s soul, things take a bleaker turn, and they never quite recover. Part of the problem is JK Rowling’s source material: there are too many characters, too much backstory and too many magical Mcguffins to keep track of. The episodic plot wanders as aimlessly as the children, culminating in the would-be tragic death of a character we’ve barely been introduced to.
On this evidence, the producers’ decision to cut the final movie in two feels like a mistake: despite some undoubted highlights, ‘Deathly Hallows Part 1’ feels like the weaker half of a still-promising film.

version.name: Machete
version.plot: Violent Tarantino spin-off with Robert DeNiro and Steven Seagal
version.review:
The grotesquely virile Trejo – the man with a face that only a stopped clock could love – stars as Machete, a former federale gone ronin. A smarmy political operative pays him US$150,000 to assassinate a xenophobic senator (De Niro) who proposes sealing the border with an electric fence, but the assignment proves to be a setup and our hero is forced to go on the lam. He wouldn’t stand a chance of eluding capture if it weren’t for the Network, a broad-based resistance organisation spearheaded by Latin spitfire Rodriguez.
An extended remix of one of the bogus trailers from Rodriguez and Quentin Tarantino’s Grindhouse diptych, this faux Mexploitation saga grinds along agreeably enough but feels weirdly overstuffed, as if the available manpower grossly exceeded a sensibly proportioned dramatis personae. Maybe that’s how Seagal wound up cast as a Mexican heavy: he sure didn’t land the part on the strength of his accent. Machete delivers the promised goods: our glowering protagonist gets the girl(s) and dishes out gory violence using gardening tools (you’d be amazed what can be accomplished with a well-tempered weed wacker).

version.name: Little Big Soldier
version.plot: Unpredictable and highly entertaining Eastern western with Jackie Chan
version.review:
The recent Karate Kid remake signalled Jackie Chan’s increasing willingness to inject a little more emotional weight into his popcorn roles, and it’s a trend he develops in Little Big Soldier, an unpredictable and highly entertaining Eastern western. Chan plays an unnamed farmer conscripted by the Liang army in their war against the Wei dynasty. When the two armies essentially wipe each other out, Chan kidnaps the Wei general and heads for home, hoping to claim a reward.
At first, the film is structured like a comic road movie, as the two leads bicker and battle across rural China, facing bears, bandits and bad guys along the way. But as the stakes rise and the violence intensifies the movie becomes richer, sadder and more engrossing: a mournful treatise on exploitation and the true cost of war, albeit interspersed with a fistful of superbly directed fight scenes. Genre-benders who like their historical slapstick buddy-action epics with a side order of political tragedy will find much to enjoy here.

version.name: The Last Flight
version.plot: Sahara-based romantic drama with Marion Cotillard
version.review: A woman sets out to find her husband after his plane disappears somewhere over the Sahara. When her plane is forced down in the desert, she meets Lieutenant Chauvet, a member of the French Camel Corps, who joins her, but it soon becomes clear an attraction is growing.

version.name: Chat Botté
version.plot: 2009 French-language retelling of the classic fairytale
version.review: This 2009 French-language retelling of the classic French fairytale by Charles Perrault follows a cunning boot-wearing feline who facilitates his master’s rise from pauper to prince with some extremely uncouth trickery.
version.director: Jérôme Deschamps, Pascal Hérold, Macha Makeïeff

version.name: Easy A
version.plot: High-school update of The Scarlet Letter with Emma Stones
version.review: Hollywood could use more Emma Stones: geeky comedians reminiscent of a young, self-deprecating Tom Hanks. So consider it a blow that Stone’s first proper star vehicle, a high-school update of The Scarlet Letter, pitches her gifts way below the mark. Don’t be embarrassed if you’d rather stay at home in her on-screen kitchen, where her dream team of parents (Clarkson and Tucci) offer supportive witticisms. Given these superb genes, you can’t help but wonder why her character, Olive, doesn’t just stay at home and leave the sub-John Hughes melodramatics to a lesser Ringwald.

version.name: The Last Exorcism
version.plot: Daniel Stamm’s faux-documentary about a charlatan exorcist
version.review:
Daniel Stamm’s faux-documentary about a charlatan exorcist confronted by a seemingly genuine demonic possession sustains its intrigue until the last 10 minutes, when a generic ending pops up and erases all of its troubling ambiguities. It’s a crushing disappointment – the immediacy of the preceding scenes is emotionally involving, psychologically disturbing and often downright terrifying.
The Reverend Cotton Marcus, an evangelical preacher who has lost his faith, invites a documentary film crew to record the truth about his final ‘exorcism’. Even when confronted by 16-year-old Nell, the lapsed believer is sceptical: fragile and naive, Nell appears more psychologically distressed than possessed. There are whispers about a faint suspicion of incest, but Nell is calmed by the reverend’s religious ministrations. Then the demons return with a vengeance.
The credibility of faux-documentary filmmaking relies on clear plotting and convincing, semi-improvised acting. German-born director Stamm is well served in both departments: Huck Botko and Andrew Garland’s script toys with our assumptions and fears. Sadly, the promise of the initial set-up and the atmospheric intensity of the central scenes are squandered by the ending.

version.name: The Next Three Days
version.plot: Fugitive-style prison break drama with Russell Crowe and Elizabeth Banks
version.review:
A decade is an eternity in an actor’s life, even among the privileged few who would try to stop the clock. Consider the case of Russell Crowe, who, in a pre-Maximus flourish, played an outraged intellectual in Michael Mann’s The Insider (1999). That role required the anxiety of a weak person thrust into heroism. For the ridiculously contrived thriller The Next Three Days, Crowe attempts to return to similar humble garb, this time as
a community-college professor – and you never buy it. The problem isn’t his paunchy intensity. You can even believably allow him a gorgeous wife, played by the charming Elizabeth Banks (teachers can dream, right?).
But in the space of a few minutes and a convoluted flash-forward structure, we learn that this union has been plagued by misfortune: she’s in prison, convicted on strong evidence for murder, and he’s a steadfast believer in her innocence. Bring on the jailbreak! Bring on the effortless operator of firearms, the expert highway driver. You keep waiting for the movie to grow a brain, for that random attractive neighbour (Wilde) to turn out to be a decoy, for Banks herself to become suspect. Nope.
The Next Three Days morphs into The Fugitive on steroids. The story started off as France’s Anything for Her (2008), itself an absurd effort. But it’s been given a special patina of self-seriousness by Crash’s Paul Haggis, who adapted the script and directs. Loosely translated, this means that after the duo are nearly smashed to a pulp, you get a quiet moment by the car in which the craziness of modern life is sadly contemplated. Or maybe it’s just the craziness of modern scripts.

version.name: Faster
version.plot: Action romp about an ex-con out to avenge his brother’s murder
version.review: In going by his real name, it looks like Johnson (who you, like us, probably know better as The Rock) is making an effort to be seen as ‘serious’ actor. He can try all he likes, but our bet is that this action romp about an ex-con out to avenge his brother’s murder will need to pull out all the stops if it’s going to be anything other than another silly gun-toting, muscle-baring cat-and-mouse tale.

version.name: Life as We Know It
version.plot: Decent romantic comedy with Katherine Heigl
version.review:
Controlling café owner Holly (Heigl) suffers through the worst blind date of her life when her best friend, Alison (Hendricks), sets her up with her husband’s best friend, caddish sports TV director Eric (Duhamel). Fast-forward three years and Alison and her spouse are killed in a car crash, leaving their one-year-old daughter, Sophie, an orphan. In a plot contrivance that’s far-fetched even for romantic comedies, the two sworn enemies move in together to raise Sophie in her late parents’ posh home.
Surprisingly, it isn’t half bad: armed with a supporting cast of professional comedians, director Greg Berlanti achieves a pleasant pace, and Duhamel seems in on the joke that he’s a self-involved pretty boy. But it’s a sorry state of affairs when Heigl is the closest approximation of a screwball-ready actor that contemporary mainstream movies can offer. Brittle, workaholic and bitterly single does not a Kate Hepburn make.

version.name: Tangled
version.plot: Masses pleasing, if formulaic, Disney animation
version.review:
An independent heroine (Moore) longing to experience the outside world; a handsome male counterpart (Levi) in need of companionship; some humdrum musical numbers. This is a transparent attempt to fill the Disney coffers by repackaging the masses-pleasing formulas that led to the studio’s early-’90s resurgence.
Rapunzel’s flowing golden locks are thrown around like Tarzan’s vines, allowing for several delirious flights of fancy, and there’s a wonderful sequence where thousands of floating lanterns light up the night sky. But there’s something synthetic about Rapunzel’s burgeoning defiance – you never feel like you’re watching a girl on the cusp of adulthood so much as a selection of attitudes compiled through demographic study. Talk about your Grimm contrivances.

version.name: Skyline
version.plot: Skyline is a terrible, terrible movie
version.review:
Let’s get one thing clear right from the off: Skyline is a terrible, terrible movie. The dialogue is abysmal (‘Vaya con dios, you son of a b****!’), the acting is even worse, the bulk of the story takes place in one LA penthouse and the plot makes absolutely no sense. For a good 45 minutes, very little happens: our heroes, Jarrod (TV veteran Balfour) and his girlfriend Elaine (Thompson) arrive in LA for the birthday bash of their successful effects-designer pal Terry, but just as they’re beginning to settle into the Hollywood lifestyle, wouldn’t you know it, aliens invade. Cue lots of flashing lights, yelling (‘We gotta get out of here!’) and fairly mediocre but intermittently impressive CGI effects.
But when the final act rolls around, it’s as if the filmmakers themselves just got bored of their own movie and decided to go a little nuts. One of our heroes gets flattened by a giant marauding bug-beast, a supporting character gets his brain sucked out, the US air cavalry pitch in to join the fight, and things start to look up. By the time one of the leading actors takes it upon himself to batter a flying squid-creature to death with a brick, it’s becoming clear that resistance is indeed futile and it’s just easier to submit to the film’s increasingly berserk parade of B-movie thrills. An extended coda tests the patience, but for a good 20 minutes Skyline fulfils its low-rent remit. Imagine it’s 1953 and you’re watching a movie called Brain Suckers from Planet X, and you might even have a good time.

version.name: The Runaways
version.plot: Music drama with Dakota Fanning and Kristen Stewart
version.review:
Wasn’t it only yesterday that Dakota Fanning shrieked her way into your splitting headache in War of the Worlds? She was just 11 back then, and in this fast-and-loose dramatisation of the flameout of the ’70s proto-grrrl group, she’s all of 15. Fanning’s co-star, vamp bait Kristen Stewart, isn’t that much more experienced (she can vote).
These two make up the film’s frontline as, respectively, blonde yowler Cherie Currie and future-bad-reputation-disregarder Joan Jett. It’s exactly as it should be; the band’s story is a cautionary one. So if you feel yourself getting protective, the movie is doing its job.
The two underage characters meet, naturally, in a bar, shoved together by creepy LA entrepreneur Kim Fowley (Shannon). Soon enough, they’re crammed into a motor home, working on chord ch-ch-changes and sliding inexorably toward drugs and Japanese fame. As styled by director Floria Sigismondi, the film mainly glances on these surfaces – it’s more giggly goofy than naughty. There’s very little pathos here for something presumably informed by Currie’s 1989 memoir. Still, there’s lots of volume in these tunes – the soundtrack is killer – and at least everyone gets their rocks off.

version.name: The Tourist
version.plot: Love story with a twist stars Johnny Depp and Angelina Jolie
version.review: The Lives of Others director Florian Henckel von Donnersmarck takes the helm here, though all the yo-yoing taking place in the director’s chair for this new flick meant he nearly didn’t make the cut. The movie follows Frank (Depp), an American tourist who takes a trip to Italy in a bid to mend his recently broken heart; while there, he meets Elise (Jolie) a savvy, extraordinary woman who crosses his path. Little has been given away about the film, but in several interviews Donnersmarck has assured audiences this is not your typical love story. Seeing is believing.

movie.name: The Chronicles of Narnia: The Voyage of the Dawn Treader

version.name: The Chronicles of Narnia: The Voyage of the Dawn Treader
version.plot: The story continues seven years after the second Narnia film
version.review: Picking up a year after the events of second film The Chronicles of Narnia: Prince Caspian, the younger Pevensie siblings, Edmund and Lucy (who, if we’d had our way, would have been throttled half-way through The Lion, The Witch and The Wardrobe – bring back Susan and Peter!) return to Narnia with cousin Eustace in tow. Joining forces with old pal Caspian, King of Narnia, they set out to rescue seven lost lords and save the nation once again. Each is tested along the way (he loves a good dose of moral quandary, does old CS Lewis), and the group encounter all manner of good and evil fantasy figures on their journey to the edge of the world. If you enjoyed the first two, this should impress. If you didn’t, perhaps give it a miss, because we’re expecting plenty more of the same.

version.name: Nativity!
version.plot: Here is a list of things that sprang to mind while watching Debbie Isitt’s festive putting-on-a-show ordeal
version.review: Here is a list of things that sprang to mind while watching Debbie Isitt’s festive putting-on-a-show ordeal, in which Martin Freeman stars as a cantankerous primary school teacher battling to stage a nativity play with the help of an infantilised tramp called Mr Poppy (Marc Wootton): film posters that depict a man shrugging while surrounded by screaming children (see Daddy Day Care, Cheaper by the Dozen and any other crèche-com you can think of); the bad Carry On films; a large-scale cloning experiment involving the kid from Jerry Maguire; films for people who don’t like films; community theatre with delusions of grandeur; a future dystopia where Simon Cowell rules by showbiz decree; the dank smell of village halls.

version.name: Fair Game
version.plot: Political thriller with Naomi Watts and Sean Penn
version.review:
Torn-from-the-headlines political scandals are frequently milked for multiplex fodder, but it’s rare that such events are spun into something as blatantly baiting as Doug Liman’s rally cry about the Valerie Plame affair (a former CIA agent outed by a Washington Post journalist in 2003).
Like its protagonist, the movie conceals its true identity. Reading the CIA riot act to an informer in Kuala Lumpur, this version of Plame (Watts) establishes both her Agency MVP authority and the tone for what seems to be a Bourne-ish globe-trotting thriller. As she handles foreign operatives in between kissing the kids goodbye, ‘Val’ comes off as another career woman balancing a hectic schedule, a soccer mum who just happens to be a spy. You wouldn’t even know the character was a famous Republican bête noire until her husband (Penn) starts glad-handing folks – ‘Hi, Joe Wilson’ – and talk turns to yellowcake in Niger.
For its first half, Fair Game balances shaky-cam espionage and a subversive cheekiness with wit and urgency. Then Plame’s cover is blown, and so is the film’s; suddenly, the clunky melodrama that had been lurking in the shadows starts hogging the spotlight. The couple’s domestic spats play for our sympathy and montages of baying media hounds inflame our ire. Lest we missed the 22-point-font messages, the movie literally ends with waving flags and a lecture. Wilson and Plame’s punishment for speaking out was indeed a repugnant abuse of power. To reduce their story to a handwringer for housewives that’s laden with protest-sign sloganeering seems, frankly, unfair.

version.name: Garfield's Pet Force
version.plot: The ginger cat with eating disorders is back on the big screen
version.review:
The sane among us recognise there’s only so much you can do with a ginger cat suffering from an eating disorder, as far as innovative storylines go. This time, the writers have decided to shame Garfield into action by throwing in a super cat named Garzooka, who claims he needs the tubby tabby’s help to save the world (really?). It also speaks volumes about a film when there’s one actor voicing nine different parts, as in the case of Weller, who not only takes charge of Garfield’s vocals, but also those of the computer voice, a dog, Keith, a Kung Fu Guard, a lawyer, a monster, a guard and the narrator, against Wingert’s comparatively slack role, voicing Jon Arbuckle (Garfield’s owner).
If the studios weren’t going to spend their dollars investing in a few more actors, we’d advise against spending your dirhams on 73 minutes of what we’d bet is just as unentertaining as the first two instalments in the grossly over-stretched franchise.

version.name: Tell Tale
version.plot: Inspired by the Edgar Allan Poe short story The Tell-Tale Heart
version.review: Inspired by the Edgar Allan Poe short story The Tell-Tale Heart, and produced by Ridley Scott, this small-time 2009 thriller – released on DVD overseas earlier in the year – sees the recipient of a new heart, Terry Bernard (Lucas), set off to find out what happened to its tragic donor, whose memories he finds himself randomly privy to. The unfortunate, if obvious, downside to this mission is that it could very well result in that heart ceasing to beat for a second time.

version.name: Lies & Illusions
version.plot: Diamond heist thriller with Christian Slater, Cuba Gooding Jr. and a twist
version.review: Self-help author Wes Wilson (Slater) is targeted by a gang of thieves searching for diamonds supposedly stolen by his dead fiancée. Wilson, bewildered by the demands, is left even more so after discovering his former beau is alive, and she claims his current girlfriend is not all she seems.

version.name: Tron: Legacy
version.plot: Keep your blue-skinned warriors, your Mad Hatters and your Gollums
version.review:
Keep your blue-skinned warriors, your Mad Hatters and your Gollums. There’s been no better use of today’s digital technology than to create a 35-year-old Jeff Bridges – several of them! – returned to ’80s-era perfection. Tron: Legacy is a feast for fans of the riding-high actor, who, as we step behind the secret door of a dusty arcade with our ostensible hero, Sam (Hedlund), greets us as both a computerised meanie (think an evil Starman) and the guru-like Kevin Flynn, now berobed, bearded and an exiled god of the machine. There’s also a version that tucks his son into bed; Bridges voices them all, dizzyingly, and the profusion of Dudes is – pardon the apt pun – game-changing. By turns a fierce megalomaniac and a Lebowskian monk, Bridges supplies more soul than any sci-fi sequel deserves.
But today’s draggy Tron has less of a reason for being than did its 1982 progenitor, which spoke intimately to a budding geek culture (come on: raise your hand). The whirring lightcycles still exhilarate, but the new film sinks a deeper anchor, briefly, during its Dark Knight-ish first third, as the gravity of real-world Ducati motorbiking and parental estrangement sets up a smarter, angrier movie than what comes to pass.
Who are we kidding? You’re going for the glowing surfaces; as a Christmas bauble, Disney’s US$200 million production doesn’t disappoint. Neither do French technobots in Daft Punk, who provide a pounding score. Then there’s Michael Sheen, playing some kind of swishy, Bowie-esque nightclub king twirling his white cane; he’s an effect in himself, and a bit too bright.

version.name: Little Fockers
version.plot: De Niro, Stiller, Polo and the rest of the cast return to pick up five years after Meet The Fockers
version.review:
De Niro, Stiller, Polo and the rest of the cast return to pick up five years after Meet The Fockers. Dubai’s comedy-loving cinemagoers shouldn’t expect any deviation from the series’ practised formula; good news for
those who loved it, one to avoid if you grew tired of the ‘circle of trust’ and slapstick gags halfway through the second movie.

version.name: Open Season 3
version.plot: Sad but true, another direct-to-DVD sequel hits the big screen in Dubai
version.review: Sad but true, another direct-to-DVD sequel hits the big screen in Dubai. Grizzly bear Boog (for those of you unfamiliar with the franchise, he’s the bother-prone protagonist) is this time trapped in a Russian travelling circus after being tricked by the circus’s own bear, and his many species of friends must rescue him. Unlike recent animations Megamind and Despicable Me, there’s very little humour for adults here.

version.name: The King of Fighters
