version.plot: Based on the video game of the same name, the US got it right when they sent this one directly to DVD
version.review: Based on the video game of the same name, the US got it right when they sent this one directly to DVD. The plot is based around the film’s namesake tournament, held in an ‘alternate dimension’, which players enter by using a kind of Bluetooth headset. Reports suggest there’s little here in the way of action for a martial arts flick, and rather too much by way of explanation. Even the trailer has been subject to a raft of scathing reviews: ‘It’s so painful to watch, it makes a root canal feel like a foot massage’ declared one. So appalling is the film expected to be, even fans of the original game have claimed they’ll be giving it a wide berth.

version.name: They Wait
version.plot: Two-year-old Canadian horror flick about Chinese-Americans
version.review: In this two-year-old Canadian horror flick, a young family return from China, where they have lived for the past six years, to North America to attend a funeral, bringing with them their young son Jamie. Soon after arriving from Shanghai, Jamie begins to see ghostly apparitions of the deceased and subsequently falls desperately ill. It’s no coincidence, of course, that their trip is timed to coincide with the Chinese Ghost Month. Given that it’s taken 24 months to get this one on Dubai’s screens, we’re expecting nothing more imaginative than a race against the clock to save the nipper’s life, by unearthing one long-forgotten dark deed or another associated with the ghoulish festival.

version.name: Season of the Witch
version.plot: Plague-related shenanigan stars Nicholas Cage as a 14th century knight
version.review: Hot on the heels of Sean Bean’s Black Death is another plague-related shenanigan set in 14th century England. A crusader (Cage – and we’ll be keeping an ear out for that accent) returns home to find it devastated by the deadly pandemic. Fearful, the church blames witchcraft and enlists our knight to cart off the chosen scapegoat (Foy) to a remote abbey where she’ll be subjected to an ugly ritual. Fate has other plans, however, and the journey turns into in a fierce confrontation over the girl.

version.name: Solitary Man
version.plot: Impressive portrait of a broken man starring Michael Douglas
version.review:
Michael Douglas has the Midas touch when it comes to mighty failures. Sure, his most iconic role, Wall Street’s Gordon ‘Greed is good’ Gekko, is the embodiment of an era’s excessive success, but the 65-year-old movie star really seems engaged only when portraying destroyed, defeated men. You can keep your repentant husbands and righteous heroes; we’d much rather take his downward-spiralling spouse in The War of the Roses and his unravelling college professor in Wonder Boys, a peerless take on muddled, middle-aged malaise. He knows how to turn losers into beautifully tarnished gold.
Add Solitary Man’s Ben Kalmen to the gallery of his greatest. Once, this car-dealership magnate had it all: a loving family, booming car lots, the world by the cojones. Then Kalmen’s doctor gives him a scare – those EKG results seem odd – and poof! Faced with his mortality, this former golden boy leaves a trail of philandering, broken promises and dodgy business deals in his wake. A seduction of his girlfriend’s teenage daughter (Poots) seals Kalmen’s fate.
Watching the way Douglas bounces his curdled, caddish charm against a well-chosen cast, you can almost forgive how directors Brian Koppelman and David Levien fall short of turning this into Wonder Boys Redux. It’s neither the final word nor the most eloquent statement on the evil that broken men do. It is, however, an impressive portrait of self-destructive, smooth-talking alpha males, and a testament to an actor who waltzes across that Peter Pan-syndrome tightrope with the greatest of sleaze.

version.name: Burlesque
version.plot: Lively musical with Cher, Christina Aguilera and Alan Cumming
version.review:
Aguilera is a plucky Midwesterner making it big in a Los Angeles burlesque club, with Cher (or is that a life-sized Cher mannequin?) as her mentor. The movie has three potential audiences. None will leave empty-handed. None will be truly sated.
Musical fans excited to see an all-singing, all-dancing rags-to-riches rollercoaster spectacular will probably feel least cheated. Connoisseurs of the compellingly bad and/or outrageously camp will find a bit to savour: notably, thudding exposition, naff design touches and a nocturnal car-park scene involving Cher, a crowbar, mutant lungs, memories and vomit. But too much of the movie is simply banal. The leads are inert, the production design boringly glossy. Crucially, the script is devoid of tension, badly paced and stuffed with distracting supporting characters, of whom only Stanley Tucci is remotely memorable.
The third potential audience – adolescent girls in search of some aspirational escapism – is the crowd to whom the film’s coy dissembling about the actual nature of burlesque does a real disservice. But there it is: try to make Showgirls for 12-year-olds and you end up pleasing no one. What a tease.
